unnormalised: **RBI's New ₹2000 Note Policy: A Comedy of Errors (and Transactions!)**
normalised: **R-B-I's New Rupee Two Thousand Note Policy: A Comedy of Errors (and Transactions!)**

unnormalised: So, the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) decided to, shall we say, "prepone" the retirement of the ₹2000 note. Suddenly, everyone's inner moneylender woke up! Queues snaked around banks like eager devotees outside a Tirupati temple. Folks were lugging suitcases filled with pink notes, looking like they'd just robbed a Bollywood set. All this for a simple exchange? It's like using a bulldozer to plant a tulsi sapling, no?
normalised: So, the Reserve Bank of India (R-B-I) decided to, shall we say, "prepone" the retirement of the rupee two thousand note. Suddenly, everyone's inner moneylender woke up! Queues snaked around banks like eager devotees outside a Tirupati temple. Folks were lugging suitcases filled with pink notes, looking like they'd just robbed a Bollywood set. All this for a simple exchange? It's like using a bulldozer to plant a tulsi sapling, no?

unnormalised: The real fun started with the vendors. My local chaiwala, Raju bhai, suddenly became a financial analyst. He'd squint at the ₹2000 note, muttering about inflation and real value, before grudgingly accepting it for my usual ₹10 cup. Auto-rickshaw walas started quoting fares in multiples of ₹2000, like they were selling plots on Mars. "Meter says Rs. 80? Haan, give me a ₹2000 note!" Negotiation skills were put to the ultimate test.
normalised: The real fun started with the vendors. My local chaiwala, Raju bhai, suddenly became a financial analyst. He'd squint at the rupee two thousand note, muttering about inflation and real value, before grudgingly accepting it for my usual rupee ten cup. Auto-rickshaw walas started quoting fares in multiples of rupee two thousand, like they were selling plots on Mars. "Meter says rupees eighty? Haan, give me a rupee two thousand note!" Negotiation skills were put to the ultimate test.

unnormalised: Then there were the jokes. Memes flooded WhatsApp groups faster than monsoon rains in Mumbai. One showed a bride draped entirely in ₹2000 notes, captioned "Shaadi Shopping Done Right!" Another featured a dog chewing on a pile of the notes, with the tag: "Even my pet is diversifying his portfolio!" The RBI must be secretly amused (or maybe tearing their hair out – hard to tell with economists, no?).
normalised: Then there were the jokes. Memes flooded WhatsApp groups faster than monsoon rains in Mumbai. One showed a bride draped entirely in rupee two thousand notes, captioned "Shaadi Shopping Done Right!" Another featured a dog chewing on a pile of the notes, with the tag: "Even my pet is diversifying his portfolio!" The R-B-I must be secretly amused (or maybe tearing their hair out – hard to tell with economists, no?).

unnormalised: The best part? Watching people try to spend these notes. Suddenly, everyone was buying groceries worth ₹1999.99. Jewelry stores saw a boom in "essential" purchases. And let's not forget the petrol pumps, where ₹200 worth of petrol was being paid for with…you guessed it! It was like a real-life game show, where the prize was getting rid of that pink elephant in your wallet.
normalised: The best part? Watching people try to spend these notes. Suddenly, everyone was buying groceries worth rupee one thousand nine hundred ninety nine and ninety nine. Jewelry stores saw a boom in "essential" purchases. And let's not forget the petrol pumps, where rupee two hundred worth of petrol was being paid for with…you guessed it! It was like a real-life game show, where the prize was getting rid of that pink elephant in your wallet.

unnormalised: In the end, the whole ₹2000 note saga became a hilarious, albeit slightly chaotic, chapter in India's financial history. Will we miss it? Maybe not. But we'll certainly have some funny stories to tell our grandkids. "Back in my day," we'll say, "we used to buy a whole pani puri plate with just one corner of a ₹2000 note!" They won't believe us, of course. But that's half the fun, isn't it?
normalised: In the end, the whole rupee two thousand note saga became a hilarious, albeit slightly chaotic, chapter in India's financial history. Will we miss it? Maybe not. But we'll certainly have some funny stories to tell our grandkids. "Back in my day," we'll say, "we used to buy a whole pani puri plate with just one corner of a rupee two thousand note!" They won't believe us, of course. But that's half the fun, isn't it?
